DOC.HEAD: Court Document Says Oakland Housing Police Stole from Undercover Officers
DOC.TEXT: Undercover investigators who went into public housing projects posing as drug dealers were beaten and robbed by housing authority police, according to a court document. The 396-page affidavit filed in a probe of the Oakland Housing Authority's 19-member force gives graphic accounts of nine alleged run-ins between investigators and housing police, including allegations that officers brutally beat unarmed investigators and pocketed more than $900 in cash. The document was unsealed Thursday. The probe of the Oakland Housing Authority and its chief, William H. Smith, was begun three months ago by the Oakland Police Department, Alameda County District Attorney's Office and the state Department of Justice. Smith previously denied any wrongdoing and any knowledge of alleged wrongdoing by his officers. His agency operates 3,300 units that house 11,000 people. Authorities began the undercover operation to investigate allegations of misconduct by the housing police, including beatings, sexual assault, theft, falsification of arrest reports and extortion. The affidavit was filed in Alameda County Municipal Court when authorities sought a search warrant. After the warrant was issued, investigators raided housing authority offices Dec. 11. Housing police, some videotaped by undercover teams, also planted drugs to bolster arrests, said the affidavit signed by Oakland Police Officer Marc Burrell. The male and female undercover officers posing as drug dealers carried large amounts of cash into the city housing projects but carried no drugs, the document said. Authorities would not comment further on the status of the investigation.
